"  Art,  three  things  so  called  (i  e.  the  word 
has  three  meanings),  viz : 

"  1.  Art  means  noble;  hence  ajic  pneAti  or 
pneAt>  Afc,  a  noble  tribe. 

"  2.  Art  means  God;  hence  Eachaidh  Finn 
Fuath-n-aiVi  was  so  called  from  his  injustice, 
fUAc  ii-Ai]ic  meaning  tJie  hatred  of  God. 
Also  Cuchullainn  is  reported  to  have  said 
after  the  death  of  Christ,  '  "Oo  nieiiiAW  Afc 
«Aj'Ab',  '  t/ie  noble  God  was  put  to  death'. 

"3.  Art   means  a  precious   stone,    whose 
diminutive,   A]icene,  meaning   small  stones, 
as  Guaire  Aidhne  said,  etc."

Ac  ipeAb,  now  Athassel,  in  the  parish  of  ReHck- 
murry,  barony  of  Clanwilliam,  and  county  of 
Tipperary,  about  three  and  a  half  miles  to  the 
west  of  Cashel,  where  an  abbey  was  founded 
about  the  year  1200,  by  William  Fitz  Adelm 
De  Burgo.  See  Keating,  reign  of  Cormac 
Mac  Art;  Annals  of  the  Four  Masters  at 
the  years  1248  and  1581 ;  and  Archdall. 
The  ruins  of  this  abbey  stand  on  one  side  of 
the  River  Suir,  wliich  was  artificially  carried 
round  the  whole  structure.  They  axe  now  very 
much  injured.

beApAC,  a  heifer.     See  biopAcb. 

beApbA,  a  dialect;  beApbA  peine,  the  Phenian 
dialect  of  the  Irish.  On  the  different  dialects 
of  the  Irish  language  Teige  O'Rody  wrote  as 
follows  in  the  year  1700; 

"  The  Irish  is  the  most  difficult  and  copious 
language  in  the  world,  having  five  dialects : 
viz.,  the  common  Irish,  the  poetic,  the  law 
or  lawyers'  dialect,  the  abstractive  and  separa- 
tive dialects ;  each  of  them  five  dialects  being 
as  copious  as  any  other  language,  so  that  a 
man  maybe  perfect  in  one,  two,  three,  or  four 
of  these  dialects,  and  not  understand  even  a 
word  in  the  other,  contrary  to  all  other  lan- 
guages, so  that  there  are  now  several  in  Ireland 
perfect  in  two  or  three  of  these  dialects,  but 
none  in  all,  being  useless  in  these  times.  I 
have  seen  several  voUmaes  that  none  in  the 
world  cm  now  peruse ;  though  within  twenty 
years  there  lived  three  or  four  that  could  read 
and  understand  them  all,  but  left  none  behind 
them  absolutely  perfect  in  all  those  books,  by 
reason  that  they  lost  the  estates  [.1.  Nemeds] 
they  had  to  uphold  their  publique  teaching, 
and  that  the  nobiUty  of  the  Irish  line,  who 
would  encourage  and  support  their  posterity, 
lost  all  their  estates,  so  that  the  antiquaryes' 
posterity  were  forced  to  follow  husbandry,  etc  , 
to  get  their  bread,  for  want  of  patrons  to  sup- 


bei 


BEI 


bes 


BES 


port  tliera.  '  Honos  alit  Aries'".  H.  2.16. 
Paper  fragment  bound  up  with  the  vellum. 
One. of  tlie  antiquaries  here  mentioned  by 
O'Rody,  was  doubtless  the  celebrated  Duald 
Mac  Firbis. 

beA|\iK\  •DeA]>5,  a  celebrated  gap  in  the  moun- 
tain 0Í  Sliabh  Caoin,  lying  on  the  borders  of 
the  counties  of  Limerick  and  Cork.  The 
road  i'rom  Kilmallock  to  Cork  passes  through 
this  gap,  which  is  situated  one  mile  to  the 
south  of  the  parish  church  of  Kilflin.  TJiis 
gap  is  well  known  to  Irish  Historians  as  the 
place  where  Mahon,  the  brother  of  Brian 
Boru,  was  murdered  by  his  Eugenian  rivals, 
in  the  year  976.  This  gap  lies  between  the 
hills  of  Kilcruaig  and  Eed  Chair,  the  former 
on  its  east,  and  the  latter  on  its  west  side.

"Cearc/iaill  (a  pillow)  is  derived  from  cervus, 
a  stag,  because  the  pillow-case  containing  the 
feathers  is  made  from  his  hide;  and  such 
case,  and  whatever  else  keeps  or  holds,  is 
called  CAib".     Cor.  Glos.  in  voce  cef  CAibl. 

biACA'ó,  refection;  biACA^o  nAi]icenn"',  periodi- 
cal refection.    H.  3.  18,  3  a.

col.  49.     See  feichem  coiche^oA. 

bi^t)l!)AnAf ,  criminality.  See  bitbeAnAf .  H.  3. 
17,  p.  193  b. 

bile  (pronoimced  beibe  in  Tipperary  and 
Waterford),  any  ancient  tree  growing  over  a 
holy  well  or  in  a  fort.  There  is  a  large  tree 
of  this  description  (called  bellow-tree  in  Eng- 
lish), growing  in  the  s.E.  end  of  the  townland 
of  Tombrickane,  in  the  parish  of  Borrisokane, 
coimty  of  Tipperary.  It  is  twenty-two  feet 
in  circumference  at  the  base,  and  has  a  hollow 
capable  of  containing  four  or  five  persons.  It 
is  held  in  peculiar  veneration  by  the  peasantry, 
who  would  not  cut  oíF  any  part  of  it  for  fuel, 
because  they  believe  that  the  house  in  which 
any  part  of  it  should  be  burnt,  would  soon 
meet  the  same  fate.

CACCAiin,  I  Impound,  confine;  "  •oon  y\]\  cacIi-

Cabati,  the  name  of  a  bird  of  the  wild  goose 
kind,  which  visits  the  coasts  of  Erris  and  Uin- 
liall,  between  the  15th  of  October  and  the 
15th  of  November,  and  sometimes  earlier;  but 
when  he  appears  earlier,  the  people  say  that 
he  brings  storms  and  hurricanes  with  him.  It 
is  generally  believed  that  he  comes  from  Shet- 
land. Dr.  Fergus,  a  native  of  Dumlia  C/iao- 
chain,  says  that  he  shot  hundi'cds  of  Cadhans, 
and  says  that  they  are  barnacle  ducks,  midway 
between  a  duck  and  a  goose  in  size.  "  The 
barnacle  fish  is  also  called  in  Irish  a  Cadlian, 
but  his  empty  shell  is  always  styled  a  51111*05". 
(Dr.  Fergus).

CAibl  gA^AbA,  an  appropriated  wood.  O'D.

CAibb  cniiiinoii,  hazels  which  inspired  the  poets. 
The  ancient  Irish  believed  that  there  were 
fomitains,  in  which  the  principal  Irish  rivers 
had  their  sources.  Over  each  of  these  fomitains 
grew  nine  hazel  trees,  which  produced  beauti- 
ful red  nuts,  Avhich  fell  into  the  foimtain,  and 
floated  on  its  surfiice ;  that  the  salmon  of  the 
river  came  up  and  swallowed  the  nuts.  It  was 
believed  that  the  eating  of  these  nuts  was  the 
cause  of  the  red  spots  on  the  salmon's  beUy ; 
that  whoever  took  and  eat  one  of  these  salmon 
was  inspired  with  the  sublimest  poetical  ideas. 
Hence  the  expressions,  "  the  nut  of  science", 
"  the  salmon  of  knowledge".  See  Dinnsen- 
chus  of  the  Sinainn,  Lib.  Lee,  fol.  240;  also, 
the  Boyish  Exploits  of  Finn  Mac  Cumliail. 

CAibbe,  a  cowl;  cen  cAibbe  |-oi\  a  cuinn,  non 
velato  capitc.     Z.  i.  194.

Camden.

Tliis  is  the  conspicuous  hill  lying  immedi- 
ately to  the  east  of  the  chui-ch  of  Dun  try- 
league,  in  the  barony  of  Coshlea,  county  of 
Limerick,  as  is  evident  from  the  following 
in  the  Annals  of  the  Four  Masters: 
1600.  O'Neill  marched  from  Cashel, 
westwards  across  the  river  Sair,  and  set  out 
for  Kinsale  by  the  route  of  Cnamh-cJioill  and 
Sliabk  na  Muice,  keeping  to  the  east  side  of 
Sliabh  Claire,  and  passing  througli  Bearna 
Dhearg  into  Clangibbon  and  Roche's  country", 
etc. 

There  is  a  large  Cromlech  in  good  preser- 
vation on  the  summit  of  this  hill,  which  seems 
to  be  the  monument  of  OlioU  Olum,  killed 
here,  according  to  the  Book  of  Lismore. 

The  summit  of  this  hill  commands  an  eS' 
tensive  view  of  the  country,  of  the  twelve 
mountains  of  Evlinné  to  the  north,  of  the 
Galties,  which  lie  at  no  great  distance  to  the 
south-east  of  Sliabh  Riach,  anciently  Sliabh 
Caoin,  which  lies  to  the  south,  and  of  a  beau- 
tiful and  fertile  country  in  every  direction.

Clni  ITIÁ1L  line  tIjAine,  a  territory  in  the  county

CLpc  jbeAnriA,  i.  e.  vallirupes,  the  name  of  the 
Knight  of  Glynn's  castle,  in  the  county  of 
Limerick.  See  description  of  this  castle  in 
Carew's  "  Pacata  Hibernia",  where  it  is  de- 
scribed as  besieged  in  1600.  See  also  JLíí- 
iials  of  the  Four  Masters,  ad  ann.  1562, 1600. 
See  also  Gleaim  Corbraighe,  infra.  Only  the 
tower  of  this  castle  now  remains.  It  is  twenty- 
one  feet  eight  inches  in  length,  and  nineteen 
feet  in  breadth  on  the  inside,  and  its  walls  are 
eight  feet  thick,  and  now  about  forty-five  feet 
high.  In  Carew's  time  the  entire  length  of 
the  building  is  described  as  one  hundred  and 
two  feet,  and  its  breadth  as  ninety-two.

CluAin  cjieÁ-ÓAil,  a  famous  monastery,  erected 
by  St.  Ita  about  the  year  569.  It  is  described 
in  her  life,  as  well  as  in  that  of  St.  Brendan, 
as  situated  at  the  foot  of  Sliabh  Luachra,  in 
the  western  part  of  the  territory  of  Ui  Conaill 
Gabhra ;  and  the  writer  of  the  life  St.  Bren- 
dan asserts  that  it  was  called  Kill  Ite  in  his 
own  time.  It  is  now  called  Killeedy;  and 
the  ruins  of  the  ancient  church  are  still 
visible  in  the  parish  of  the  same  name,  lying  in 
the  barony  of  Glenquin,  county  of  Limerick, 
about  five  Irish  miles  to  the  south  of  the 
town  of  Newcastle.  See  Irisli  Calen.,  15th 
January,  and  Life  of  St.  Ita,  as  given  by 
Colgan,  at  the  same  day ;  Acta  SS.  p.  66.

Cnoc  Patjuuij,  a  conspicuous  hill  in  the  parish

of  Limerick ;  on  the  top  of  this  hill  there  is 
an  old  church,  said  to  have  been  originally 
built  by  St.  Patrick. 

Cnoc  ■RA'ponn,  a  parish  and  townland  in  the 
barony  of  Middlethird  and  county  of  Ti])pe- 
rary,  about  two  miles  north  of  Cahir,  where 
there  are  a  rath  and  a  moat  of  great  size,  and 
the  ruins  of  a  castle,  erected  by  the  English  in 
1192.  The  moat  is  fifty-five  feet  in  perpen- 
dicular height,  and  sixty  feet  in  diameter  at 
top.  Sec  Annals  of  the  four  Masters,  ad 
ann.  1192,  and  Keating  at  the  reign  of  Cor- 
mac  Mac  Art.

Cuile<3.nti,  a  man's  name  in  ancient  Ireland.  It

CtiilleAun  Oj-CuAUAch,  now  CuUen,  a  village 
originally  in  the  barony  of  Coonagh,  county 
of  Limerick,  on  the  border  of  the  parish  of 
Sulchóid,  in  the  county  of  Tipperary.     See 
Annals  of  the  Four  Masters,  at  the  year  157y, 
and  Book  of  Lismore,  fol.  i!30,  a  a.,  where  it

Mac    Cumhail.      Though   this   village    was

name  indicates,  it  is  now  considered  as  belong- 
ing to  the  barony  of  Clanwilliam,  in  the  county 
of  Tipperary.

Cor.  Glos.  in  voce  •OAJ. 

"OA  cic  X)AnAinne,  i.  e.  the  two  Paps  of  Danann. 
Two  mountains  in  the  barony  of  IMagunihy, 
and  county  of  Kerry,  called  the  Eastern  and 
Western  Pap.  The  Eastern  Pap  is  situ.ited  in 
the  boundary  of  Gortdarrig,  and  divides  the 
parishes  of  Killaha  and  Kilcnmming;  the 
Western  Pap  is  on  the  boundary  of  the  to-wn- 
land  of  Gortacreen,  and  divides  the  parishes 
of  Killaha  and  Kilcummin  East.  Both  are 
nearly  of  equal  height,  are  very  round,  and 
appear  very  beautiful  at  some  distance,  and 
both  have  small  heaps  of  stones  on  the  very 
summits,  intended  evidently  to  represent  the 
nipples  of  the  paps.  The  base  on  which  they 
stand  is  called  bun  a  ■oa  cic,  basis  duarum 
mammarurn.

'O^Mi\c,  a  heifer  two  .years  old,  worth  four  scre- 
palls  (H.  3.  18,  p.  513),  classed  among  the 
■|-écu  cúica.  See  Sec.  A  cow  is  worth  twenty- 
four  screpalls;  a  colpach,  six  screpalls ;  and  a 
samhaisc,  twelve.  These  are  multiples  of  each 
other:  one  samhaisc — half  a  cow  ;  one  colpach 
— half  a  samhaisc ;  one  dairt — half  a  col- 
pach; one  dartaidh — half  a  colpach.  See  H. 
3.  17;  O'D.  110.

Annals  of  Inii' fallen,  at  the  year  976;  but 
his  son  Cathal,  who  commanded  the  Hy- 
Fygeinte  at  the  battle  of  Ciontarf,  in  the  year 
1014,  is  called  chief  of  Cairbre  Aobhda;  and 
at  the  year  1200,  Amlafl'O'Donovan,  his  des- 
cendant. Is  called  king  of  Cairbre  Aobhdha. 
O'Heerin,  who  died  in  1420,  thus  speaks  of 
the  country  of  the  representative  of  this

A  olcAf".  Droichet,  derived  from  the  verb 
■oojioicber,  they  pass,  because  people  pass 
over  it  from  one  brink  of  the  water  or  stream 
to  the  other ;  or  Dj'och-Sket,  i.  e.  a  straight 
pass ;  for  droch  means  everything  straight,  i.  e. 
there  is  no  curvature  in  it,  that  it  may  not 
be  slippery;  or  Droch-Shet,  a  bad  road  or 
pass  because  it  is  a  bad  one.  Co7\  Glos. 
"  If  bAlf  'OO  fOUAU  'Of oiceAcc  nA  V^iffi

T))\uini  AiuncAch,  now  Drviminagh,  or  Castle 
Biggs,  near  the  margin  of  Lough  Dcrg,  in

"Ofuim  "OAiiiJAife,  now  Knocklong,  in  the

"Of  mm  inliif,  now  Drumineer,  in  the  baiony  of 
Lower  Ormond,  and  county  of  Tipperary, 
about  five  miles  N.  and  by  w.  of  the  town  of 
Nenagh.  It  is  mentioned  in  the  Book  of 
Lecan,  in  the  pedigrees  of  the  Muscraighe 
Thire,  as  the  seat  of  O'Luinin.  The  name 
signifies  the  ridge  near  the  Inver,  or  mouth 
of  the  river,  which  is  descriptive  of  the 
locality.  There  is  a  curious  ancient  chiirch 
here,  near  Inver,  and  a  square  castle,  said  to 
have  been  built  by  the  family  of  Butler. 

"Ofuim  f AileAc,  a  ridge,  in  the  parish  of  Bour-

to  the  south  of  the  town  of  Roscrea.     It  is 
now  generally  called  Bawnmadrum,  from  an 
old  castle  that  stands  on  it.  See  Four  Masters, 
ad    ann.    1601.     The   following   passage   in 
O'Hecrin's    topographical    poem     puts    the 
situation  of  this  hill  beyond  dispute :

"Oub-AlJAinn,  a  river  mentioned  by  Keating  as 
forming  a  part  of  the  boundary  between  the 
dioceses  of  Limerick  and  KiUaloe.  It  is  now 
called  the  Blackwater  river.  It  is  formed  by 
a  number  of  small  streams,  rising  in  the  parish 
of  Kilseely,  in  the  barony  of  Lower  Tidla, 
and  county  of  Clare,  and  uniting  at  the  south 
side  of  the  same  parish.  It  flows  through  the 
parishes  of  St.  Patrick's  and  Kiltenanlea,  and 
falls  into  the  Shannon  opposite  Newcastle, 
about  two  miles  to  the  east  of  the  city  of  Lime- 
rick.

"Oun  Aicet),  a  celebrated  fort  in  the  county  of

"Oun  Áine  cliAc,  a  fort  erected  by  Brian  Bora 


DUN 


•ouuVi 


DUTH 


on  the  summit  of  the  western  division  of 
Knockalne,  in  the  barony  of  Small  County, 
and  county  of  Limerick ;  about  two-and-a- 
half  miles  from  Brufi".  It  is  forty-one  paces 
in  diameter,  and  is  now  much  eifaced. 

X)iin  bLeifce,  a  fort  in  the  territory  of  the  Hy- 
Cuanach,  where  a  St.  Fintan  erected  a  church 
in  the  sixth  century.  See  Leabhar  Breac, 
fol.  30.  Colgan  and  Lanig;m,vol.  ii.  p.  232. 
It  is  the  present  village  of  Doon,  in  the 
barony  of  Coonagh,  county  of  Limerick,  about 
twelve  miles  east  of  the  city  of  Limerick. 
The  site  of  the  old  church  of  St.  Fintan  is 
now  occupied  by  a  modern  church,  but  his 
holy  well  is  still  in  existence,  bearing  his 
name ;  it  is  situated  in  a  grove  of  fir  trees,  in 
the  east  corner  of  the  townland  of  Killmoylan, 
Lower. 

"Oun  GocAi]i  iiiAije,  the  ancient  name  of  Bruree, 
in  the  county  of  Limerick.  See  Keating, 
reign  of  Brian  Boru;  see  also  Cnoc  SAiiinA, 
supra.  "Oiiti  GocAi]!  tllAije  signifies  the 
fort  on  the  brink  of  the  Maigue. 

"Oún  iiA  Tii-beAnn,  now  Dunnamann,  in  the 
parish  of  Croom,  containing  the  ruins  of  a 
square  castle  of  considerable  height. 

"Oún  tiA  ■pciAc,  now  Dunnaskeagh,  a  townland 
in  the  parish  of  Rathlynin,  in  the  barony  of 
Clanwilliam,  county  of  Tipperary,  where 
Carthach,  the  ancestor  of  the  M'Carthys,  re- 
sided in  1043.  M'Carthy's  seat  was  on  the 
top  of  a  round  hill  in  this  townland;  and 
about  half-a-mile  to  the  north  of  the  hill 
there  was  a  stone  castle,  which  is  now  nearly 
destroyed.     See  Four  Masters,  1043. 

"Oún  CHÍ  t-iAj,  now  Duntryleague,  about  three 
miles  to  the  north-west  of  the  village  of  Gal- 
bally,  and  nine  miles  to  the  east  of  Kilmal- 
lock.  It  is  in  the  parish  of  Galbally,  and 
barony  of  Coshlea.  A  fort  was  erected  here, 
according  to  Keating,  by  the  famous  emperor 
of  the  Scots,  Brian  Boiu;  but  I  could  find 
but  very  small  traces  of  it  in  the  summer  of 
1840.  It  was  situated  near  the  modern  church 
of  Duntryleague.  There  is  a  very  remark- 
able cromlech  on  the  hill  to  the  east  of  this 
church.  See  Four  Masters,  at  the  year  1054. 

"Oun  Hi  pAolÁin,  a  fort  on  the  bank  of  the  river 
Suir,  to  the  west  of  1ni|-  LeAiimAccA,  about 
one  mile  to  the  west  of  the  town  of  Clonmel, 
in  the  barony  of  Iffa  and  Otfa  West.  This 
fort  was  in  existence  in  Keating's  time,  but  it 
is  now  entirely  levelled.  See  Keating  in  the 
reign  of  Cormac  MacArt,  and  Inij-  LeAni- 
nAccA,  infra. 


"OupLA]',  a  strong  fort,  now  Anglicised  Thurles. 
There  is  a  very  remarkable  fort  called  1\ac 
•oúi\tAi]',  in  the  parish  of  Kilruane,  in  the 
south  end  of  the  barony  of  Lower  Ormond, 
county  of  Tipperary.  This  fort  is  of  very 
large  dimensions,  and  has  three  circrJar  de- 
fensive embankments,  and  two  deep  trenches. 
Near  it  is  a  circular  castle  which  goes  by  the 
same  name.  It  is  four-and-a-half  miles  west 
of  the  village  of  Toomavara,  or  UuAnn  Hi 
nieAt))\A.  This  fort  has  the  ruins  of  a  small 
ancient  church  within  it.

"OúnÚAch,  a  penitentiary;  a  house  of  austerity, 
rigour,  and  penance.  The  general  length  of 
an  Irish  Durthacli  was  fifteen  feet,  and  the 
breadth  ten  feet.  For  a  curious  account  of 
the  price  paid  for  the  penitentiary,  cathedral, 
and  round  tower  of  the  Irish,  see  MS.  in 
Trin.  Coll.,  H.  3.  17,  p.  G53,  and  Petrie's

■pé,  a  rod  wliich  was  used  by  the  Pagan  Irish  for 
measuring  bodies  and  graves.  It  is  stated  in 
Cormac's  Glossary  that  it  was  always  left  on 
one  of  the  graves  in  the  cemetery,  and  that 
the  people  had  an  abhorrence  of  taking  it  up 
in  their  hands.  Some  Ogura  characters  were 
insciibed  on  it.

5Al,t-bo,iie  GAchoipL<\c,  now  Galbally,  a  village 
in  the  barony  of  Coshlea,  in  the  s.E.  of  the

jAoiblic,  alias  j:;Ao-ó<Ml5e,  the  Irish  language. 
This  is  always  called  Scotica  lingua  by  Adam- 
nan,  and  sometimes  in  Cormacs  Glos.  (see 
CAcAb).  Adamnan,  who  was  born  in  the  year 
624,  in  his  first  preface  to  the  Life  of  Columb- 
CiVe,  gives  us  to  understand  that  it  was,  like 
all  the  other  external  languages,  rude  and 
inelegant : 

"  And  let  them  not  despise  the  narration 
of  those  facts,  which  are  useful,  and  which 
happened  not  without  Divine  aid,  on  account 
of  the  occurrence  of  Scotic  names  of  men, 
tribes,  and  places ;  for  that  language  (in  my 
opinion)  Is  rude,  and  to  be  ranked  with  dif- 
ferent other  languages  of  the  external  na- 
tions".    Colgan's  and  Pinierton's  Editions.

5o)\c  riA  ciob]iAC,  i.e.  field  of  the  spring,  now 
Anglicised  Springfield.  It  is  an  old  square 
castle,  in  a  townland  of  the  same  name,  in  the 
parish  of  Killagholehane,  in  the  south  of  the 
county  of  Limerick.  It  adjoins  the  house  of 
Lord  Muskerry.  This  is  mentioned  in  the 
Antials  of  the  Four  Masters,  at  the  year  1579, 
and  by  O'Siilhvan  Beare,  in  his  History  of 
the  Catholics,  where  he  renders  it  "  ager 
fontis",  and  in  Brnith's  Collections,  about  the 
Siege  of  Limerick.

5]uaII,,  gravel,  sand.     (Donegal.)

5)nAn,  land,  ground.  "  pine  5^111",  the  ori-

See  511111. 

^]nMii,n,  terra  Solaris,  solarium,  pergula.  1.  a 
beautiful  surmy  spot,  as  5l^iAnÁn  CAbiiuije, 
in  the  coimty  of  Shgo.  2.  a  bower  or  summer- 
liouse.  3.  a  balcony  or  gallery.  4.  a  royal 
palace.  In  the  third  and  fom-th  sense  here 
set  down,  this  word  is  very  frequently  used  in 
the  old  Irish  historical  tales  and  romances. 
The  erection  of  a  jniAnÁn  is  thus  described 
in  a  very  old  historical  tale,  entitled  "  ITleu 
iDjAicjieAnn".  "  Then  did  Bricreann  erect  a 
Grianan  near  the  couch  of  Conchubhar  and 
those  of  the  heroes.  This  Grianan  he  formed 
of  gems  and  various  rich  materials,  and  placed 
on  it  windows  of  glass  on  every  side.  One  of 
these  windows  he  placed  over  his  own  couch, 
so  that  he  might  see  the  whole  e.xteut  of  the 
great  house  out  of  it".  Leabhar  na  li  Vidhri. 
For  the  meaning  of  Grianan,  see  Acta  SS. 
p.  13,  note  6 ;  Keating,  in  the  reign  of 
Laogliaire  Mac  Neill;  translation  of  Ogijgia 
II.  p.  315;  Annuls  of  the  Four  Masters,  Dr. 
O'Conor's  edition,  p.  653;  Adventures  of 
Connall  Gulban,  Trinity  College,  class  H.  Í. 
7,  and  CrabUs  Dictionary  in  Lib.  R.I.A.  in 
voce  summer-house ;  and  Ordnance  Memoir, 
under  Grianan  of  Aileach,    See  quotations  at

Inif  LeAtimAccA,  now  Inishlunaght  or  Abbey, 
one  Irish  mile  to  the  west  of  the  to^vn  of 
Clonmel,  in  the  barony  of  Iffa  and  Oifa  East, 
and  county  of  Tipperary.  There  was  an 
abbey  founded  here  in  1187  by  Donnell 
O'Brien,  King  of  Limerick,  and  jNIalachy 
O'Faelain,  King  of  the  Desies ;  but  it  is  now

river  Suir.  See  Keating,  in  the  reign  of

"LeAC-junA,  a  demi-cannon,  of  which  there  are 
three  sizes:  "  1.  The  lowest  dcml-cannon  is 
a  great  gun  that  carries  a  ball  of  thirty 
pounds  weight,  and  six  inches  diameter;  the 
diameter  of  the  bore  is  six  inches,  two-eighth 
parts.  2.  Demi-cannon  ordinary,  a  great 
gun,  six  inches  four-eighths  diameter  in  the 
bore,  twelve  feet  long ;  it  carries  a  shot  six 
inches  one-sixth  diameter,  and  thirty-two 
pounds  weight.  3.  Demi-cannon  of  the 
greatest  size,  a  gun  six  inches  and  six-eighths 
diameter  in  the  bore;  twelve  feet  long;  it 
carries  a  ball  of  six  inches  five-eighths  dia- 
meter, and  thirty-six  poimds  weight".  John- 
sons Dictionary.  The  Four  Masters  use  this 
word  under  the  year  1580.

Li  op  nA  coibbe,  now  LisnacuUia,  or  Woodfort, 
a  townland  in  the  parish  of  Cloouagh,  in  the

1420.     See  Fitzgerald's  History  of  Limerick.

III0  "Oe  bnoc,  my  God-judge  or  God  of  judg- 
ment; an  exclamation  said  to  have  been 
originally  used  by  St.  Patrick,  and  afterwards 
adopted  by  others.  "  lllo-oebjiot,  ol  Pachaic, 
quod  Scotici  corrupte  dicunt;  sic  hoc  dici 
debet.  Ilium  "Oiu  b]iAiic;  a  mum  -om  if 
mens,  An  -out  if  Deus,  An  bjiAUc  if  judex  .1. 
Meus  Deus  judex  .1.  bfeiciiii".  Cor.  Glos. 
This  phrase  is  used  by  IMaurice,  the  son  of 
Paidin  O'lMulconry,  in  his  prose  version  of 
the  Old  Book  of  Fenagh.  It  is  variously 
explained  by  the  writers  of  the  lives  of  St. 
Patrick ;  but  the  above  Interpretration,  given 
in  Cormacs  Glossary,  and  the  following,  by 
Jocelyn,  are  the  most  satisfactory:  "  Quoties 
tamen  magna  necessitate  ductus  cogebatur 
verbum  suum  certificare  per  judiceni  suum 
jurando  solebat  illud  confirmare".  Cap.  Ib5. 
See  quotation  at  cumAic.  Triad.  Thau.  p. 
106.  See  H.  3. 17,  col  25  [III0  "Oe  bp oc  beóf] 
"  Respondit  Patricius  eo  [Angelo].  Dar-mo 
Dhe  broth  .1.  Potens  est  Deus  si  velit  hoc 
prajstare.  Genus  autem  jurarnenti  erat  Patricio 
familiare,  Dar  mo  Dhe-hroth,  hoc  est,  ac  si 
diceret,  per  Deum  meum  Judicem  sivejudicii 
Schoiiastes  Fieccheanus"  (9  i.).  Triad.  Thau.  p. 
4  b.  "  Et  ait  S.  Patricius  ad  cos  Modehroth, 
quod  interpretatur,  quod  non  laboratis  non 
proderit  vobis".  Probus.  Lib.  11.  cl.  XII. 
Triad.  Tliau.  p.  53.  Cui  irascens  S.  Patricius, 
cum  male  dictione  dixit  3Iadebrot,  quod 
potest  intelligi  male  fecisti,  nunquam  proficiet 
tibi;  sed  ager  hie  tuus,  neque  tibi,  neque  se- 
minituo  in  aeternum  imquam  utilis  erit".  Idem. 
Lib.  II.  cl.  XXVIII.     Triad.  Thau.  p.  59.

íleirtieAt).  Besides  these  the  word  neimeAt)  has 
four  other  meanings;  viz:  a  musician,  a 
carpenter,  a  smith,  a  cow;  but  the  word  is  said 
to  be  differently  compounded  when  applied 
to  either  of  these — thus:  when  it  signifies  a 
musician,  it  is  said  to  be  compounded  of  nerii 
and  ot),  music ;  when  it  signifies  a  carpenter, 
it  is  compounded  of  neiii  and  inoú,  or  ireic,  a 
shape  or  form;  when  a  smith,  of  neiii  and 
ABt),  fire;  and  when  a  cow,  of  netii  and  yvt, 
milk.  These,  however,  are  visionary  deriva- 
tions, and  it  is  probable  that  neiriicAt)  in  these 
is  from  radically  different  words,  which

TlAim|-eAc  ■puAU,  two  stones  in  the  townland  of 
Curraun,  in  the  parish  of  St.  MulHns,  barony 
of  Bantry,  and  coimty  of  Wexford.  Accord- 
ing to  tradition,  St.  Moling  metamorphosed 
the  wife  of  the  Gobán  Saer  and  her  companion 
into  these  stones.  A  blacksmith  who  lives  in 
the  vicinity  states  that  he  made  three  small 
grooves  in  the  larger  of  these  stones,  with  a 
view  to  having  it  blasted;  but  that  when 
he  was  about  to  apply  the  powder  he 
saw  di'ops  of  blood  oozing  from  the  holes, 
which  convinced  him  that  TlAiTni-eAC,  the 
Gobán's  wife,  was  still  Hving,  and  her  blood 
circulating,  under  the  appearance  of  a  rude 
rock.

great  cow  and  six  heifers,  the  six  heifers 
being  equal  to  three  cows.  H.  3.  18,  p.  i)?.

Sibinne,  rushes;  "fibinne  pntijlA^A",  green- 
topped  rushes.     O'D.  2108 ;  Raid.  487. 
Sicbe,  whatsoever;  "ficbe  pAec";  C.  791. 
Sit),   pj.       "  The    Irish",    says    the    learned 
O'Flaherty,  "  called  aerial  spirits  or   phan- 
toms i'í'óe,  because  they  are  seen  to  come  out 
of  pleasant  hills,  where  the  common  people 
imagine  they  reside,  which  fictitious  habita- 
tions are  called  by  usp-óe  or  pot)A".    Ogygia, 
p.  200.     Peter  O'Connell  thought  that  fí-óe 
was  a  figurative  name  for  hills,  because  they 
were  imagined  the  habitations  of  fairies.   The 
word  is  more  probably  derived  from  ptie,  a 
blast  of  wind,  which  may  figuratively  signify 
"  an  aerial  or  spiritual  heing'\  similar  to  the 
Latin  word  spiritus,  which  originally  signified 
"  breath",  and  the  Greek  Trvsvfia.     The  Irish 
considered  these  púe  the  gods  of  the  earth. 
The  Book  of  Armagh,  which  was  written  a.d. 
834,  contains  a  very  curious  passage  in  which 
this  word  is  explained:  "Deinde  autem  venit 
Sanctus  Patricius  ad  fontcm  quem  dicitur  Cla- 
bach  in  lateribus  Crochan,  contra  otium  solis 
et  sederunt  juxta  fontem,  et  ecce  dure  fihaj

riim,  cmn  Patricio  juxta  fontem  invenenmt; 
ct  quocumque  essent,  aut  quacumque  forma

ConpAi  mic  'OAipi".  Glendaloitgh,  fbl.  105. 
I  viewed  these  moimtains  from  Cnoc  Aine  on 
the  5th  August,  1840,  and  found  this  descrip- 
tion remarkably  correct.  On  the  maps  by 
Speed  and  others  in  the  reign  of  Queen

hills  of  Phelemghe  Modwena.  In  the  Book 
of  Glendalough.  fol.  105  a,  b,  the  whole 
range  is  called  SliAb  n-G-bbmm  injini 
ghuAipe.  These  twelve  mountains  of  Slcibhte 
Eibhlinne  extend  from  within  eight  miles  of 
Limerick,  in  the  direction  of  Nenagh  and 
Cashel;  the  nearest  of  them  to  Limerick  is 
called  gC'^pp-^n  DÁn  ;  the  neai'est  to  Nenagh  is 
called  Céiri  lIpmuiiiAin  ;  and  the  nearest  to 
Cashel,  t)Ápp  haScuac,  or  Dundrum;itis 
four  miles  to  the  west  of  Cashel. 
StiAb  eilbe.  Slieve  Elva,  a  mountain  in  the 
parish  of  Killonaghan,  barony  of  Burren,  and 
county  of  Clare.  It  is  mentioned  in  ÚieLife 
of  Senamis,  and  in  the  Caithreiin  Thoirdheal- 


bhaiij.  The  highest  point  of  this  mountain, 
which  is  in  the  townland  of  Fanaroosk,  is 
1,133  feet  above  the  level  of  the  sea.  On  the 
top  of  this  mountain  is  a  small  lough  called 
Loc  Giibe,  Elva's  lake  or  pool.  A  small 
stream  flowing  through  the  townland  of  Kil- 
moon,  and  called  .AbAinn  CAiticin,  divides 
Sliabh  Eilbhe  and  Blake's  mountain.  There 
is  also  a  large  hole  in  the  townland  of  Cooleabeg, 
parish  of  Kilmoon,  and  at  the  foot  of  this 
mountain,  called  polb  Gilbe. 

SbiAb  gcpoc,  a  mountain  in  the  south  of  the 
barony  of  ClanwiUiam,  in  the  county  of  Tip- 
perary, at  the  foot  of  which  the  old  church  of

SbiAb  nA  m-bAn  pionn,  i.e.  mons  mulierum  can- 
didarum,  a  large  mountain  in  the  county  of

SbiAb  nA  muice,  now  Slievenamuck,  a  low

lying  between  the  town  of  Tipperary  and  the 
Glen  of  Aharlow,  about  two  miles  to  the

Masters,  at  the  year  1500.  It  extends  from 
Bansha  to  Corderry,  within  a  mile  of  the 
village  of  Galbally.

óij\  A5Ap  Aijijicc  AjAp  jAc  peoic  Ap  cbenA", 
Four  Masters,  1020.  This  passage  is  incor- 
rectly translated  by  Colgan  in  Triad,  p.  298, 
which  is  strange,  as  he  generally  translates  the 


Four  Masters  most  accurately.  We  shall 
give  his  translation,  and  our  own  correction  in 
parenthesis.  "1020.  Ardmaoha  tota  inccndio 
vasta  usque  ad  (recte  simul  cum)  arcem  ma- 
jorem  (arci  majori)  in  qua  nulla  domus  fuit 
combusta  (recte  servata)  prajtcr  Bibliothecam 
solam.  Sed  (recte  Et)  plurimse  aedes  sunt 
flammis  absiunptas  in  tribus  aliis  partibus 
civitatis,  et  inter  alia  ipsum  summumtemplum 
(turris  cum  ejus  campanis)  Basihca  ToLnisis, 
Basilica  Sabhallensis,  Basihca  rectus  concio- 
natoria  (currus  abbatialis) ;  libri  omnes  stu- 
diosorum  in  eorum  domiciliis  et  ingens  eopia 
auri  et  argenti  cum  aliis  plurimis  bonis".  Con- 
nell  Mac  Geoghagan  translates  this  passage 
correctly  from  the  Annals  of  Clonmacnoise. 
"  Ardmach,  the  third  of  the  Kallends  of  June, 
was  burnt  from  the  one  end  to  the  other  save 
onlie  the  Librarie  (ceAc  pc]\eA)DcpA) ;  all  the 
houses  were  burnt,  the  great  church  (■oonti- 
biAcc  tiió]\),  steeple  (cboicceAcb),  the  church 
of  the  Sabhall,  the  pulpitt  or  ciiair  of  preach- 
ing (cACAoip  ppoicepcA)  togetlier  with  much 
gold,  silver,  and  books  were  burnt  by  the 
Danes".

Ciob)iAix)  A]\An,  UipjAAt)  A^iAn,  ie.  the  well  of 
Ara,  now  the  town  of  Tipperary,  which  is  situ- 
ated in  the  territory  anciently  called  Ara 
Cliadi.  The  well  from  which  this  town  took 
its  name  is  now  closed  up.  It  was  situated  on 
the  north  bank  of  the  river  Ara,  at  the  rear 
of  Mr.  O'Leary's  house,  the  front  of  which  is 
in  the  main  street  of  Tipperary.  It  was  closed 
up  by  Mr.  O'Leary  some  years  since.  All  the 
natives  are  positive  that  the  great  well  oppo- 
site the  church  of  this  town  is  not  the  ancient 
Tibraid  Aran.  Smith,  in  his  MS.  collections 
for  a  history  of  the  county  of  Tipperary,  re- 
marks that  Heersheba,  the  well  of  the  oath, 
gave  name  to  the  adjoining  city  of  Beersheba. 
(Gen.,  cap.  xxii.).  Compare  with  O'Brien's 
Dictionary.

UojA,  choice,  selection:  "  Deipit)  pnn^eA^A 
y^ey  coja",  the  senior  takes  a  free  choice. 
H.  3.  18,  p  145  a.  This  ride  applies  to  the

among  a  tribe.  The  senior  got  his  choice  of
